corpus.text: John Stuart Mill's harm principle: Actions should only be restricted to prevent harm to others. Self-regarding actions are protected from interference. Distinguishes harm to others (legitimate restriction) from self-harm or offense (not legitimate). Foundational to liberalism.

corpus.text: John Stuart Mill's harm principle from 'On Liberty' (1859) states that individual actions should only be limited by society to prevent harm to others. Core tenets: (1) Self-regarding actions - those affecting only oneself - should never be restricted even if harmful to the individual, (2) Other-regarding actions can be restricted only to prevent direct harm to others, (3) Mere offense, disgust, or moral disapproval don't constitute 'harm', (4) Competent adults are best judges of their own interests. Implications: opposes paternalistic laws (seatbelts, drugs), supports free speech even if offensive, permits any consensual adult behavior. Challenges: defining 'harm' (physical only? economic? psychological?), indirect effects (do all actions affect others?), children and incompetent persons exempt. Central to liberal political philosophy, influenced First Amendment jurisprudence, debates on victimless crimes. Critics argue it's too individualistic, ignores social nature of humans.
